Author: zandorg
Content:
I learned from a Media Studies course that distribution and promotion costs 100% of the cost of a movie. So a $30 mil movie costs another $30 mil to promote. Unless of course you get promotion by saying how much it cost!

[Additional] I loved the Hunt for Gollum and that was astonishing film making for the budget.

Author: jchrisa
Content:
@antirez the thing is that CouchDB is designed for replication. Every CouchApp is a p2p web app. This is different from the web we've known before.

CouchDB will never be as fast as some other k/v stores, but http based peer replication gives us a robust offline mode (and portable api) so that applications can run at the Edge.

Like this: http://www.slideshare.net/jchrisa/couchdb-to-the-edge

Author: daleharvey
Content:
rmdb's are a ridiculous way to run a chat application, other databases like mnesia (used heavily for ejabberd) work pretty well.

storage and querying are pretty typical functional requirements, I dont know how much more suited couchdb would be for chat than mysql, but you cant dismiss it because of the same preconceptions you have with other "databases"

Author: tallanvor
Content:
They compete for students. They compete for professors (both those who will attract students and those who will attract grant money). They compete for peer recognition.

If colleges believe they can offer a 3 year degree that will result in students who are able to compete against students with a 4 year degree, they will do so. And, to be honest, a couple will probably try.

The format of higher education in America has been evolving for close to 400 years. During that time, many ideas have been tested, and you can still find a few colleges that are very different than the norm. However, the vast majority look similar in terms of how degrees are structured because that is what was found to be the most effective in preparing students for a career after they graduate.

You can argue over whether or not whether the traditional methods are best, but at the end of the day they work for the majority of students here. And, of course, the quality of higher education in America is high enough to attract people from all over the world.

At the end of the day, you don't have to take my word for it - just look into some of the research that's been done, both in terms of curriculum and general student development, and you'll get an idea as to just how much time is being put into determining the best ways to help students learn and grow.

Author: tptacek
Content:
Added bassist Mike Dirnt, more succinctly but just as effectively: "As the biggest record store in the America, [Wal-Mart] should probably have an obligation to sell people the correct art."

Where does this logic end? At what level of "bigness" are you no longer allowed to decide what you're willing to sell? Are you allowed to draw any lines about content? Green Day can't sell at Wal-Mart because they won't strip swear words out of their record. What about overt racism?

Best just to let the market handle this. Green Day is doing the right thing; it's not that Wal-Mart is rejecting them, it's that Green Day is effectively boycotting them. Great. One step closer to the day when we stop selling bits on little plastic disks.

Author: noss
Content:
Interesting extract:

"Microsoft’s new search engine would lump results into categories specific to the query. For example, a search for a product may return photos, manufacturers’ Web pages and reviews, as well as places to purchase the product, according to one of the people. Each category would be included in a menu on the left side of the screen, with related searches and past searches listed in a panel below the category tabs. "

Author: Alex3917
Content:
On the other hand, the arguments that FDA is using today to combat the use of checklists (also for sterilization) are almost exactly the same.

These arguments make a lot of sense when there is a common cognitive error. For example, the cognitive error that caused mistake A is also causing mistake B. I don't have enough domain expertise to say whether or not that was the case in this article, for its intended purpose.

Author: rgh
Content:
I own a cleantech company, mainly small utility photovoltaics, in Australia a tradesman (a tradie) working with solar energy earns a minimum of $70Kpa (US$ 54K) and if he owns a company which employs 6 other tradies, he will earn over $1 million a year.

In Australia, the marketer even have a term CABs (cashed up bogans) a bogan is similar to a urban redneck.

I have often heard complaints from very high level government officials, that every time they increase the government funding of solar energy, all that happens is the tradies increase their prices.

In Australia, similar to many European pays up to 75% of the cost of installing solar energy equipment.

Richard Hayes Carbon Free Solutions
